title: How to Display a Glass Collection

steps.headline: Obtain or build a lighted curio cabinet.
steps.description: Look for one with shelves spaced for the height of your items. Shell collectors and insect collectors actually have special boxes with glass lids made that can slide out of their cabinets like drawers.

steps.headline: Build shelving to fit a window opening.
steps.description: A set of glass shelves attached to a window frame would bring the natural light through your glass collection and could be admired from both inside and outside your home.

steps.headline: Use a baker's rack or plant stand.
steps.description: These are generally made of widely spaced wire mesh or rods, so you would need to place a shelf (preferably clear glass) over the wires to allow the items to sit level while still allowing maximum light through.

steps.headline: Mount multiple smaller shelves on a wall to display smaller groups of glassware.
steps.description: This is not recommended for heavier pieces, however, as they require more solid support and nobody wants large glass vases and figurines suddenly cracking through their shelves and shattering on the floor.

steps.headline: Alternatively, you could simply utilize areas in your home.
steps.description: For instance, windowsills are excellent for smaller items and other horizontal areas (book shelves, top of the piano, coffee tables, end tables) work for the remaining larger items.

text: Obtain or build a lighted curio cabinet. Look for one with shelves spaced for the height of your items. Shell collectors and insect collectors actually have special boxes with glass lids made that can slide out of their cabinets like drawers. Build shelving to fit a window opening. A set of glass shelves attached to a window frame would bring the natural light through your glass collection and could be admired from both inside and outside your home. Use a baker's rack or plant stand. These are generally made of widely spaced wire mesh or rods, so you would need to place a shelf (preferably clear glass) over the wires to allow the items to sit level while still allowing maximum light through. Mount multiple smaller shelves on a wall to display smaller groups of glassware. This is not recommended for heavier pieces, however, as they require more solid support and nobody wants large glass vases and figurines suddenly cracking through their shelves and shattering on the floor. Alternatively, you could simply utilize areas in your home. For instance, windowsills are excellent for smaller items and other horizontal areas (book shelves, top of the piano, coffee tables, end tables) work for the remaining larger items.
